entry.title: The Great Divide in Personality
entry.content:
Carl G. Jung, a Swiss psychiatrist who founded analytical psychology, distinguish the great divide between two personalities‚Äìextroverts and introverts‚Äìour society has been geared towards extroversion ideals. In the #Culture of Personality, we follow those who are confident and assertive than those who are reticent and unassuming 1. Researchers estimates 50-70% that make up the population are extroverts, whilst 16-50% were introverts. 2

Of course, personality has different flavors; its not always yin and yang of personality. If you take the The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) test, there are actually 16 types of personalities based on the theory of psychological types explained by Jung 3. The purpose of this test is to make the type theory accessible to individuals and groups, and to help individuals find their a suitable profession for their type.

Although MBTI is a paid service and is restricted for use only to certified professionals 4, there is a free online personality test similar to MBTI that is more accessible to anyone who desires to know their type 5.

entry.title: Culture of Character to Culture of Personality
entry.content:
In the Culture of Personality, people focus on how others perceived them and aspire to be bold and entertaining. ‚ÄúThe social role demanded of all in the new Culture of Personality was that of a performer,‚Äù Warren Sussman, influential cultural historian, famously wrote. ‚ÄúEvery American was to become a performing self.‚Äù As opposed to the Culture of Character where ‚Äúthe ideal self was serious, desciplined and honorable‚Äù. People value not so much as the impression they make in public but as how they behave in their privacy. The word personality weren‚Äôt even invented until the eighteenth century, and the idea of ‚Äúhaving a good personality‚Äù was not widespread until the twentieth. 1

A shift from the Culture of Character to the Culture of Personality brings new wave of cultural ideals# from which we would never quite recover.

entry.title: Step Four: Have a Plan
entry.content:
The final step of #The Framework for Changing Habits, is to establish a plan of action to begin to shift your behavior.

The hardest part of habit change, even equipped with the knowledge of your cue, is making the conscious effort to steer away from doing your routine. Sometimes you forget and sometimes you just don‚Äôt have the willpower to defy your urge. Hence, study after study concluded that having a plan is the easiest way to accomplish something. Not just having a plan in mind, it‚Äôs as if writing in water, but having it in a piece of paper is more powerful.

Say, through reward experimentations, your finding indicates you quench your sweet tooth by eating a chocolate bar and a working alternative is to bite an apple instead. Your plan of action should be: ‚ÄúWhenever I feel the need to take a chocolate bar, I will grab an apple instead.‚Äù Better, if you know what time you usually snack, ‚ÄúAt 4:30, I will go to the cafeteria and grab a fruit‚Äù.

Specificity is key. The more specific your are with your plan, the easier it is to follow.

Additionally, plan ahead for when you succumbed to your urges. After all, we are creatures who act according to our urges. It‚Äôs how we survive. You may choose to punish yourself for it, better yet have a plan of action for when you capitulate. Sometimes, you won‚Äôt have enough willpower to stick to your rule after a long day of work. For instance, instead of eating a fruit you grabbed a cookie. You may write on your plan: ‚ÄúWhen I grabbed a cookie instead of a fruit, I will only eat half of it.‚Äù Still, you satisfied your cue to eat something sweet but it‚Äôs a win nonetheless, because you resisted to eat the whole thing and abided by your plan.

You may add a few more rules to your list, but be sure to make it simple, concise, actionable and specific. Not too complicated of a plan to overwhelm yourself, but not too simple that you might ignore it.

Resources

entry.title: Step Three: Isolate The Cue
entry.content:
After #figuring out the _why_ (reward), it is time to find the what or the cue to your persisting habit.

Most of the time, the cue to our habit is very simple but is often overlooked. Our brain processes multiple inputs simultaneously from our basic senses.

We see through our eyes, hear through our ears, or feel with our skin. We make sense of the world with our basic survival skills. But often times, it is also an impediment to our learning. A psychologist at the University of Western Ontario came up with a solution as to why some eyewitnesses remembered better than others. After watching overwhelming amount of questioning footages, she figured out a pattern by focusing on few important elements at a time: the questioner‚Äôs tone, the facial expression of the witness, how close the questioner and the witness were sitting to each other.

To isolate the questioner‚Äôs tone, she turned down the volume until all she can hear was the tone of their voices. To focus on the facial expression of the witness, she taped the questioners face. To measure their distance, she used a tape measure onto the screen.

Later on, it came to her that most eyewitnesses who were questioned by cops in a gentle manner tend to misremember what happened to the incident. ‚ÄúIn other words, when environmental cue said ‚Äòwe are friends‚Äô‚Äìa gentle tone, smiling face‚Äì ‚Ä¶Subconsciously those friendship cues triggered a habit to please the questioner.‚Äù1

The takeaway from the eyewitnesses experiment is to separate the important elements from the rest to figure out the underlying pattern. We can use this to isolate only key elements that may cause our habit to be triggered. Experiments have shown that almost all habitual cues fit into one of five categories:

  • Location
  • Time
  • Emotional State
  • Other people
  • Immediately preceding action

For example, having the urge to drive by fast-food restaurant:

Location:                     Driving home on the free way
Time:                         3:36pm (after work)
Emotional State:              Lethargic
Other People:                 None
Immediately preceding action: Getting in the car

Next day:

Location:                     Driving home on the free way
Time:                         3:46pm (after work)
Emotional State:              Stressed
Other People:                 None
Immediately preceding action: Getting in the car

After working out:

Location:                     Driving home from the gym
Time:                         5:33pm
Emotional State:              Burned out
Other People:                 None
Immediately preceding action: Getting in the car

And so on‚Ä¶

Once you have enough information to ascertain that a pattern emerge‚Äìlike driving home after a stressful activity‚Äì, you are one step closer to changing your habit. Figuring out your habit‚Äôs routine, reward, and cue is of no trivial feat and that you should be proud of yourself. However, there is one final, and probably the most important step: Step Four: Have a Plan#
